title: Regina King simply stuns in a black thigh-baring gown ahead of her debut as a superhero in Watchmen
text:
She's taking a starring role after spending most of her career helping other people shine with stellar supporting work.

And Regina King is ready for her superhero debut in Watchmen as she graced the November cover of Marie Claire with supreme elegance.

The 48-year-old actress sported gorgeous black gowns for the series where she detailed her rise to becoming a coveted icon in the entertainment industry.

Standing strong: Regina King is ready for her superhero debut in Watchmen as she graced the November cover of Marie Claire with supreme elegance

Regina portrays cop Angela Abar who transitions into Sister Night in the Damon Lindelof creation which premieres on Oct. 20.

'Sister waited until she was almost 50 to be a superhero,' King said. 'It's something I've always wanted to do, you know, be a woman physically kicking ass.'

She's metaphorically spent years 'kicking ass' at the box office and earned a coveted Best Supporting Actress Academy Award this year for her role in If Beale Street Could Talk.

While she's finally getting the well-deserved accolades for her abilities in front of a camera, the dream to create didn't necessarily begin with acting.

'My desire to be a career actor was not always my desire,' she said. 'I thought I was going to be a dentist. It's funny because I've dated only one guy with not-so-great teeth, and I dated him for a minute. I never said anything, and after we broke up, he gets his teeth fixed.'

Regina remembered running into her ex one day 'and he's wearing Invisalign.'

She insists that while growing up, her mother Gloria always encouraged her (and younger sister Reina) to pursue the arts and stay creative regardless of the task at hand.

Gloria also taught her children that 'thinking attracted your fate' and to align your mind with what you wanted to achieve.

'My desire to be a career actor was not always my desire,' she said. 'I thought I was going to be a dentist'

'What my mother filled us with, what she gave us, it feels natural and so intuitive,' she said of her abilities to attract fate. 'The Secret was never a secret for me.'

And while she's excited for her new venture on HBO, she's committed to learning and growing from her experiences.

'I'm very good at choosing what needs to stay with me and what things need to be let go of,' she said. 'Sometimes we can get so caught up in the moment and we don't ever leave that moment, and that's how some people get stuck. I don't know if you ever heard me say, "Comfort zones are where dreams go to die."'
